Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of equipment for high speed optical communications research and education at College of Staten Island

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches
The objective of this research is to study advanced communication technologies, parallel computation techniques and model arbitrary signal generation and detection using a versatile, programmable experimental platform that will be assembled using the obtained equipment. The approach is to integrate this platform with an existing high-performance computer to automatically generate, detect and process high-speed, multi-level optical signals. This can be programmed to experimentally study the performance of high spectrally-efficient optical signals and support the study of real-time high-speed data analysis.

Intellectual Merit
The experimental platform offers the novel capability of flexible software-controlled reconfiguration of a single experimental setup to perform comprehensive performance evaluations of arbitrary modulation formats for different network applications and to study key aspects of adaptive electronic compensation schemes. It takes advantage of the high performance computing engine to provide massive parallel digital signal processing capability and reduce the required time for data processing by replacing offline processing, which is currently used by most high-speed experiments, with real-time online processing. It thus enables research on high speed communications (beyond 100Gbps) with complex modulation formats, improved performance and on a variety of optical system application spaces.

Broader Impacts
The proposed work will strengthen our student?s exposure to graduate and undergraduate research here on Staten Island as well as improve their interactions with the high-tech industry. It will also bring together students and faculty within the City University of NY to study multidisciplinary problems and enable recruitment of underrepresented minorities and/or women students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was instrumental in establishing a major research laboratory on photonic communication systems and networks at the College of Staten Island (CSI) of the City University of New York (CUNY). The MRI funded the acquisition of a pair of high speed signal generator and oscilloscope (serve as a signal receiver) to build a state-of-the-art testing platform for cutting-edge research in optical communications and comprehensive training in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields.

Optical communications and networks are major carrier for today's telephone, television, and internet traffic. To handle various social networks and more and more smart-phone applications,   optical communication systems and networks must be able to carry more data at a faster speed and a higher quality. The versatile testing platform developed at the CSI can perform very high speed experiments at a speed of 40 gigabits per second and higher. It has become an important testing tool to help researchers and engineers to conduct advanced R&D on very high speed optical communication systems and networks.

The state-of-the-art testing platform is a flexible, re-configurable, versatile experimental testing system that can perform comprehensive performance evaluations for optical components and optical systems under different advanced modulation formats. It has enabled and facilitated several cutting-edge researches on high speed, high capacity, long-haul transmission systems over single mode fiber (SMF) for telecommunications and data communications and broadband short reach communications through plastic optical fiber (POF) for avionics applications.

The versatile experiment testing platform has greatly enhanced the current experimental facilities in Engineering and Sciences at the CSI which is the only public higher education institution in Staten Island. This testing platform enables faculty and students at the CSI as well as from other campuses of the CUNY to conduct innovative research in photonics and telecommunications with hands-on experiences.  This testing platform provides a comprehensive learning environment for our graduate and undergraduate students to develop a wide skill-set via integration of theoretical study and experimental practice. This project has stimulated multiple collaborations between our school and other academic institutions or industries. It has improved undergraduate research and senior design courses by engaging our undergraduate STEM students in a research intensive learning environments.
